description:
Athalia rosae, commonly known as the Rape Sawfly or Rape Blossom Sawfly, is a species of sawfly that belongs to the family Tenthredinidae. It is a small insect, typically measuring around 8-10 millimeters in length, with a black or dark brown body and yellow or reddish-brown legs.

The Rape Sawfly is found across Europe and parts of Asia, where it is considered a pest of various brassica crops, such as rapeseed (Brassica napus), cabbage (Brassica oleracea), and mustard (Brassica juncea). The larvae of the Rape Sawfly feed on the leaves and stems of these plants, which can result in significant damage and reduced yields if left unchecked.

The life cycle of the Rape Sawfly typically involves multiple generations per year, with the adults emerging in the spring and laying their eggs on the host plants. The larvae hatch and feed on the plant material, eventually pupating in the soil before emerging as adults to continue the cycle.

Due to its economic importance as a pest, the Rape Sawfly has been the subject of extensive research, particularly in the development of integrated pest management strategies to control its populations and minimize the impact on agricultural crops.
